study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of nurse-led Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) on reducing suicidal ideation, hopelessness, and depression in hospitalized elderly suicide survivors.
results_summary: The study found that MBCT significantly reduced scores on the Suicidal Ideation Scale, Beck Hopelessness Scale, Patient Health Questionnaire-15, and Geriatric Depression Scale at 6 months compared to conventional care. Multiple logistic regression confirmed MBCT as a key factor in these improvements.
population_specificity: Hospitalized elderly suicide survivors (middle-aged and elderly patients).
study_duration: Follow-up at 3 and 6 months (intervention duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in alleviating anxiety and enhancing Quality of Life (QOL) in Stage III breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy with mild-moderate anxiety disorders.
results_summary: MBCT significantly improved anxiety scores (HADS-A) and certain aspects of QOL (EORTC QLQ-C30 function and symptom scores) compared to psychoeducation alone, though its impact on global QOL scores was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Stage III breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy with mild-moderate anxiety disorders.
study_duration: March to June 2023 (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore ACS patients' symptoms, needs for behavioral health treatment, perspectives on mindfulness intervention via videoconferencing, and willingness to participate in self-collection of dried blood spots to guide MBCT adaptation for a future clinical trial.
results_summary: Participants with depressive symptoms experienced emotional, physical, social, and health behavior problems, while those without depressive symptoms made positive health behavior changes but struggled with anxiety. Both groups were interested in behavioral health treatment, and most were willing to participate in a mindfulness group via videoconferencing.
population_specificity: ACS patients (N = 23; 13 with elevated depressive symptoms, 10 without; 63.4 years average age, 87% male, 96% non-Hispanic white).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether an online modified Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) intervention could improve mental health outcomes and caregiving quality in the primary caregivers of children with allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: The study found that online MBCT effectively reduced caregiver burden, alleviated anxiety and depression, and increased mindfulness levels in caregivers. The intervention was deemed applicable and beneficial for this population.
population_specificity: Primary caregivers of children with allergic rhinitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of MBCT on depressive symptoms, brain potential, and neuroimmunoinflammatory factors in patients with depression.
results_summary: MBCT combined with conventional therapy significantly reduced depressive symptoms and inflammatory markers (tumor necrosis factor α and interleukin-6), improved quality of life, and enhanced attention and response to target stimulation compared to conventional therapy alone.
population_specificity: 64 patients with depression, divided into control and observation groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) with Behavioral Activation Treatment for Anhedonia (BATA) in reducing anhedonia symptoms in a transdiagnostic cohort of adults.
results_summary: MBCT showed comparable efficacy to BATA in reducing anhedonia symptoms, with no significant differences in treatment effects or symptom improvements. Both interventions demonstrated similar reductions in anhedonia and internalizing symptoms.
population_specificity: Adults with clinically significant anhedonia (transdiagnostic cohort).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility of online mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (eMBCT) in reducing depressive symptoms for individuals with treatment-resistant depression (TRD) in a clinical setting.
results_summary: The eMBCT group showed significant improvements in depression and anxiety symptoms, with large effect sizes, while the control group exhibited no significant changes. The intervention also led to notable reductions in depression symptoms and improvements in clinical global impressions compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Outpatients aged 18 and above diagnosed with treatment-resistant depression (TRD) at the Institute of Psychiatry of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a group-based mindfulness intervention (MBCT) integrated into an inpatient stroke rehabilitation program compared to standard care, focusing on depression, anxiety, mindfulness, and attention.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in primary outcomes (depression and anxiety) between the MBCT and standard care groups. However, there was an improvement in the trait mindfulness observing subscale favoring the intervention group.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients in an inpatient rehabilitation setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical therapeutic effect and mental state improvements of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in patients with functional dyspepsia (FD).
results_summary: The study found that MBCT significantly improved gastrointestinal symptoms, reduced anxiety and depression levels, and enhanced sleep quality, though it did not affect gastric emptying.
population_specificity: 80 patients with functional dyspepsia from an outpatient clinic.
effective_dosage: Not specified (MBCT therapy was administered in addition to rabeprazole and mosapiride).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and efficacy of web-delivered Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) for treating depression, including its impact on symptoms, psychiatric distress, and secondary outcomes like stress and mindfulness.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, with preliminary enrollment data (30 participants out of 224 screened). Results will assess MBCT's feasibility, efficacy in reducing depression symptoms, and its effects on secondary outcomes, with full analysis expected by August 2024.
population_specificity: Adults with current, residual, or chronic depression symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in reducing anxiety and depression symptoms in people with Parkinson's disease (PD) and explore its effects on motor symptoms, stress markers, and PD progression biomarkers.
results_summary: The study is a prospective randomized controlled trial (RCT) investigating MBCT's effects on anxiety and depression in PD patients, with additional exploratory outcomes on motor symptoms, stress markers, and PD biomarkers. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: 124 PD patients with mild-moderate anxiety and depression symptoms, disease duration ≤10 years, eligible for MRI, and naïve to mindfulness.
effective_dosage: 8 weeks of MBCT (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) in alleviating depression and anxiety in older adults.
results_summary: The study found a significant moderating effect of MBCT against depressive symptoms (g = 0.53) and anxiety (g = 0.43) in older adults, though caution is advised due to limited studies and potential publication bias.
population_specificity: Older adults with depression and anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effects of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) compared to an active control (Seeking Safety) in alleviating PTSD symptoms in individuals with subthreshold PTSD.
results_summary: The study will assess MBCT's effectiveness in improving PTSD symptoms, with primary outcomes measured by the PTSD checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5) post-intervention. Secondary outcomes include improvements in depression, anxiety, attention, experimental avoidance, rumination, mindfulness, and coping skills.
population_specificity: Individuals with PTSD symptoms (subthreshold PTSD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of virtually delivered Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) for pregnant individuals experiencing psychological distress.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a pilot trial to evaluate MBCT's feasibility and explore group differences in psychological symptoms during the perinatal period, but results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals aged ≥18 years, between 12 and 30 weeks of gestation, experiencing a range of psychological symptoms.
effective_dosage: Eight weekly group sessions, each focusing on mindfulness practice, discussion, and skill development.
study_duration: Eight weeks, with follow-up at three months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictive and response biomarkers by examining the relationship between clinical domains and resting-state network connectivity in OCD patients undergoing MBCT.
results_summary: MBCT modulated connectivity in the ventral default mode network (vDMN) and frontostriatal network (FSN), potentially reducing symptoms across clinical domains. Each clinical domain had unique baseline brain connectivity patterns, suggesting symptom-based biomarkers.
population_specificity: Twelve patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) improves sexual desire, arousal, distress, and mind-body awareness in women with low sexual interest compared to supportive sex education.
results_summary: MBCT showed more pronounced improvements in sexual and affective responses compared to supportive sex education, with increased sexual concordance predicting reduced sexual distress. Gains were sustained at 6- and 12-month follow-ups.
population_specificity: 148 cisgender women with low sexual interest or impaired sexual response.
effective_dosage: Eight weekly group sessions (specific duration per session not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of Mixed-mode Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (M-MBCT) on psychological resilience, self-esteem, and stigma in schizophrenia patients.
results_summary: M-MBCT significantly reduced stigma (ISMI scores) and increased psychological resilience (CD-RISC scores) and self-esteem (RSES scores) in schizophrenia patients compared to standard treatment. Age, education, and family history of mental illness were identified as factors related to stigma.
population_specificity: 174 inpatients with schizophrenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify moderators of treatment effect (depressive symptoms and well-being) of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) compared to Positive Psychology Intervention (PPI) and treatment as usual (TAU) in patients with bipolar disorder.
results_summary: The study found that patients with more severe depressive symptoms benefited more from MBCT than PPI. Other variables associated with better response to MBCT included higher baseline anxiety, lower well-being, and being married.
population_specificity: Patients with bipolar disorder.
study_duration: Outcomes were assessed at baseline, posttreatment, and 12 months after baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of pain acceptance, specifically pain willingness and activity engagement, in the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy for Migraine (MBCT-M).
results_summary: The study found that pain acceptance, pain willingness, and activity engagement were negatively correlated with headache-related disability. Activity engagement increased more in the MBCT-M group compared to the control, and changes in these factors mediated improvements in disability.
population_specificity: 60 participants with migraine (31 in MBCT-M group, 29 in waitlist/treatment-as-usual group).
study_duration: Baseline to one-month post-treatment, with 6-month follow-up for MBCT-M group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) and Mindfulness-Integrated Cognitive Behavior Therapy (MiCBT) in terms of their origins, structure, and evidence base.
results_summary: MBCT has a substantial research base and is endorsed for preventing depressive relapse, though its single-disorder focus may limit broader applicability. MiCBT shows promise for transdiagnostic use but requires more high-quality RCTs and systematic reviews.
population_specificity: Individuals with depression (for MBCT) and transdiagnostic applications (for MiCBT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mediating roles of self-compassion and alexithymia in reducing psychosomatic distress among somatic symptom disorder (SSD) patients undergoing Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT).
results_summary: The study found that MBCT led to significant improvements in psychosomatic distress, mediated by increases in self-compassion and reductions in alexithymia. A post-hoc analysis suggested that alleviation of alexithymia preceded improvements in self-compassion, both contributing to reduced distress.
population_specificity: 116 SSD patients (76.7% women, mean age 40.0) who completed ≥4 MBCT sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) versus dry cupping on fertility quality of life and conception success in infertile women with PCOS.
results_summary: MBCT significantly improved fertility quality of life scores compared to cupping therapy, but no significant difference was found in conception rates between the two groups.
population_specificity: Infertile women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) referred to health centers affiliated with Shiraz University of Medical Sciences.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pre-treatment brain morphological metrics, specifically pallidum volume, could predict the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) compared to psycho-education (PE) in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
results_summary: Both MBCT and PE groups showed significant reductions in Y-BOCS scores, with MBCT demonstrating a larger reduction. Pallidum volume was identified as a predictor of treatment effectiveness, where a larger pre-treatment volume correlated with a greater reduction in OCD symptoms.
population_specificity: 32 patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (10-week MBCT or PE program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and limited efficacy of two formats of online mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (eMBCT)—group, blended and individual, unguided—for people with cancer.
results_summary: Both eMBCT formats showed positive participant experiences, with group, blended eMBCT having higher session completion rates (9.7 vs. 8.3). Effect sizes were small to moderate, with group, blended eMBCT showing moderate effects on fatigue and individual, unguided eMBCT showing moderate effects on mindfulness skills and engagement.
population_specificity: People with cancer
effective_dosage: 8-week eMBCT program (10 sessions total: 1 introductory, 8 regular, 1 silent day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) improved symptoms of insomnia in individuals with recurrent depression.
results_summary: MBCT significantly reduced insomnia severity, sleep onset problems, and nocturnal awakenings compared to controls, but did not affect early morning awakening, daytime impairment, or dissatisfaction with sleep. The results suggest MBCT improves certain insomnia symptoms, though additional sleep-specific interventions may be needed.
population_specificity: Remitted participants with at least three prior episodes of depression (74.5% female, mean age 40.7 ± 12.9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effectiveness of MBCT-C to traditional CBT, including a parent module, and assess the feasibility of adding a parent module in preventing childhood internalizing difficulties.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but indicates that MBCT-C has similar effects to CBT as a targeted preventive program, with ongoing evaluation of longer-term outcomes and parent module benefits.
population_specificity: Children aged 9-12 with signs of internalizing difficulties (e.g., shy, withdrawn, worried) and their parents, recruited from socio-economically disadvantaged primary schools in South Australia.
effective_dosage: 10 group sessions for children, 2 parent-only group sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of online group Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) for Chinese outpatients with depression by comparing it to the traditional offline format.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in depression (HAMD-24) and anxiety (HAMA) scores in both medicated and unmedicated patients, with faster improvements in medicated patients. However, no significant changes were observed in self-reported depression (SDS), mindfulness (MAAS), or self-acceptance (SAQ) scores.
population_specificity: Chinese outpatients with depression (n=75, with 44 taking psychotropic medication).
effective_dosage: 10-week online group MBCT sessions (schedule and content matching traditional MBCT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) improves cognitive functioning and BDNF levels more than Psychoeducation and treatment as usual (TAU) in bipolar disorder patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between MBCT, Psychoeducation, and TAU in improving cognitive functions or BDNF levels, suggesting MBCT did not outperform the other interventions. The authors proposed that the efficiency of Psychoeducation and TAU, along with the short duration of MBCT, may explain these results.
population_specificity: Bipolar disorder outpatients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy improves adherence to immunosuppressive therapy in liver transplant recipients.
results_summary: The experimental group receiving Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy showed significantly increased adherence to immunosuppressive therapy post-intervention (p < 0.01), while the control group exhibited lower adherence and mindfulness levels in the posttest phase. The study concluded that Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy is effective in promoting therapy adherence.
population_specificity: Liver transplant recipients (n = 120) hospitalized at a liver transplant department.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and acceptability of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy-Taking it Further (MBCT-TiF) for graduates of MBCT and MBSR in improving mental well-being compared to Ongoing Mindfulness Practice (OMP).
results_summary: MBCT-TiF was significantly more effective than OMP at improving mental well-being, with large post-intervention effects (Cohen's d = 0.78). No serious adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 164 graduates of MBCT/MBSR programs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of mindfulness-based programs on improving sleep quality in healthy, non-institutionalized older adults.
results_summary: Mindfulness significantly reduced poor sleep quality in older adults with both long-term and short-term sleep disorders, showing moderate negative effect sizes across different sleep assessment tools (ISI, PSQI, SOL). The results were statistically significant and consistent.
population_specificity: Healthy, non-institutionalized older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of self-help mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT-SH) on mindfulness, depression symptoms, and suicidal ideation in patients with depression.
results_summary: MBCT-SH significantly improved mindfulness by week 4 and showed significant reductions in depression symptoms and suicidal ideation by week 8, with sustained effects at 3-month follow-up. It also reduced treatment costs without significantly affecting readmission rates.
population_specificity: Patients with depression (n=97, randomized to MBCT-SH or control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the dose-response effect of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) on college students with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: MBCT significantly reduced depression (PHQ-9), anxiety (GAD-7), and poor sleep (PSQI) scores, lowered pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α), and increased mindfulness (FFMQ), self-compassion (SCS), and BDNF levels compared to the wait-list group. Greater daily practice and session attendance correlated with higher symptom reduction rates.
population_specificity: College students with major depressive disorder (MDD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily practice time and session numbers were tracked but not quantified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy adapted for suicidal individuals (MBCT-S) in reducing suicidal ideation and related symptoms compared to treatment as usual (TAU).
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in suicidal ideation, depressive symptoms, hopelessness, worrying, defeat, and entrapment in the MBCT-S group, along with increased mindfulness, both post-treatment and at follow-up. The intervention group showed greater improvements than the control group receiving only TAU.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ experiencing suicidal ideation.
study_duration: 12 weeks post-training follow-up (intervention duration not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a customized Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy program (MBCT-vision) could treat Visual Snow Syndrome (VSS) and modulate dysfunctional visual network connectivity.
results_summary: MBCT-vision significantly improved symptom severity, daily life impact, wellbeing, and distress scores at Weeks 9 and 20 compared to baseline. fMRI analysis also showed modulation of visual network functional connectivity.
population_specificity: 21 participants (14 male, median age 30, range 22-56) with Visual Snow Syndrome.
effective_dosage: 8-week MBCT-vision treatment program (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy-"Taking it Further" (MBCT-TiF) improves mental well-being through changes in mindfulness, self-compassion, and decentering compared to ongoing mindfulness practice.
results_summary: MBCT-TiF significantly improved mental well-being through increases in mindfulness, self-compassion, and decentering, with similar benefits for depression. Only mindfulness and decentering mediated improvements in psychological quality of life and anxiety.
population_specificity: 164 graduates of MBCT and mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acceptability and potential efficacy of a web-based mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (COMPANION) for couples in reducing chronic fatigue in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, with data collection expected to conclude by March 2024. Benchmark values for acceptability and efficacy were predefined, but final results are not yet available.
population_specificity: Couples (cancer patients with chronic fatigue and their partners).
effective_dosage: 9 sessions of web-based intervention (psychoeducation, mindfulness, and cognitive-behavioral exercises).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up assessments occur at T0 (baseline), T1 (2 weeks post-intervention), and T2 (1 month after T1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in improving OCD symptoms and identify socio-demographic, clinical, and neurobiological factors mediating or moderating the response.
results_summary: The study is an ongoing RCT assessing MBCT's efficacy in reducing OCD symptoms, with comprehensive evaluations of clinical, neuropsychological, and neuroimaging variables to identify potential biomarkers of response. Results are pending as the study is not yet completed.
population_specificity: 60 OCD patients who did not respond to first-line treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore state- and trait-level effects and potential mechanisms of four Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) practices in a general population.
results_summary: The study found state-level improvements in self-compassion, mindfulness, and pleasantness of thoughts/emotions/body sensations, but no between-group differences. Trait-level improvements were seen in psychological quality of life and some mechanisms, though again no between-group effects were observed. Changes in mindfulness and self-compassion were linked to better psychological quality of life.
population_specificity: 160 adults self-selected from the general population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the added value of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) compared to treatment as usual (TAU) for individuals with bipolar disorder (BD) over a 15-month follow-up period.
results_summary: MBCT + TAU was not more effective than TAU alone in reducing depressive symptoms post-treatment or at follow-up, though it improved mindfulness skills post-treatment. Participants with higher baseline depressive symptoms and functional impairment showed greater benefits from MBCT + TAU.
population_specificity: 144 participants with bipolar disorder type I and II.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in cognitive fusion and pain catastrophizing over 8 weeks of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy for migraine (MBCT-M) compared to a waitlist/treatment-as-usual group.
results_summary: MBCT-M significantly reduced pain catastrophizing scores compared to the control group, but cognitive fusion scores did not change significantly. Decreases in pain catastrophizing mediated improvements in headache disability in the MBCT-M group.
population_specificity: 60 adults with migraine

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cost-effectiveness and cost-utility of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) combined with treatment as usual (TAU) compared to TAU alone in adults with Bipolar Disorder (BD).
results_summary: MBCT + TAU showed lower total costs and a small but favorable difference in quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) compared to TAU alone, resulting in a dominant incremental cost-utility ratio. The probability of MBCT + TAU being cost-effective was 65%, with sensitivity analyses supporting the robustness of these findings.
population_specificity: Adults with Bipolar Disorder (N = 144).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether MBCT reduces social anxiety in individuals with alopecia areata (AA) and whether it also improves depression, general anxiety, quality of life, and trait mindfulness.
results_summary: Four participants showed reductions in social anxiety from baseline to follow-up, with greater effects observed at follow-up than post-intervention. Two participants demonstrated significant improvement in standardized wellbeing measures, correlating with regular mindfulness practice between sessions.
population_specificity: Individuals with alopecia areata (AA) experiencing social anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness and cost-benefit of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) from healthcare and employer perspectives.
results_summary: MBCT showed potential cost-effectiveness from a healthcare perspective (92.2% probability at a threshold of £30,000 per QALY) and cost-benefit from an employer perspective (net monetary benefit of JPY 106,460). The intervention improved work productivity and QALYs.
population_specificity: 50 healthy participants meeting inclusion criteria (25 in MBCT group, 25 in wait-list control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy in improving sleep quality in older adults with subclinical and moderate insomnia.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in insomnia symptoms in both subclinical and moderate intervention groups, as measured by the Insomnia Severity Index and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy was deemed effective for treating insomnia in older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults with subclinical or moderate insomnia (n = 106, ages not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physiological and psychological benefits of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) for breast cancer survivors by analyzing pooled data from randomized and non-randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that MBCT significantly reduced anxiety, pain, and depression levels while increasing mindfulness among breast cancer survivors, though the results were marked by moderate to high heterogeneity for some outcomes.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms through which the digital Mindful Mood Balance (MMB) program delivers its benefits and its differential impact on mindfulness, decentering, and rumination compared to usual depression care alone.
results_summary: The MMB program significantly improved decentering, mindfulness, and rumination compared to usual depression care alone, and these changes mediated subsequent depressive relapse. The findings suggest digital delivery of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy effectively modifies key processes linked to depressive relapse.
population_specificity: Predominantly White, female participants with residual depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to refine and evaluate the feasibility of a trauma-specific Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (TS-MBCT) intervention for women with PTSD/CPTSD due to domestic violence and abuse, and assess its potential for a full-scale RCT.
results_summary: The refined TS-MBCT intervention showed high acceptability, 100% retention, and feasibility for a full-scale RCT, though recruitment and control arm randomization faced challenges. PTSD/CPTSD outcomes did not rule out clinically important differences, suggesting further evaluation is warranted.
population_specificity: Women who experienced domestic violence and abuse (DVA) with PTSD or CPTSD.
effective_dosage: Eight group sessions plus home practice (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) on core symptoms, emotional dysfunction, and executive function in patients with Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), as well as assess its feasibility and acceptability.
results_summary: MBCT participants showed greater improvement in BDD symptoms, emotion dysregulation, and executive function compared to the treatment-as-usual group, with partial support for executive function tasks. Feasibility and acceptability of MBCT were positive.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility and process of change during Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in patients with chronic noncancer pain and opioid use disorder (OUD).
results_summary: MBCT was not feasible for most patients due to barriers like timing, group format, and somatic complaints, but the four participants reported reduced opioid craving and improved pain coping.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with chronic noncancer pain and OUD undergoing rotation to buprenorphine/naloxone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) could reduce psychological distress, improve sleep quality, fatigue, and quality of life in patients with Inflammatory Bowel Diseases (IBD).
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it hypothesizes that MBCT will effectively reduce psychological distress and improve sleep, fatigue, and quality of life in IBD patients, with potential broader applicability to other chronic conditions.
population_specificity: IBD patients in remission, aged 16+, with at least mild psychological distress (HADS total score ≥ 11).
study_duration: Assessments at baseline, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months follow-up (intervention duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of brain iron levels on depression severity and cognitive function in individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD) treated with mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT).
results_summary: MBCT treatment provided depression relief, improved executive function and attention, and enhanced verbal learning and memory in MDD participants with specific baseline brain iron levels. Lower iron levels in certain brain regions were associated with greater treatment benefits.
population_specificity: Seventeen unmedicated individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD) compared to fourteen healthy controls (HC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore potential mechanisms through which Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) improves depressive symptoms in patients with Treatment-Resistant Depression (TRD).
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness skills mediated the effect of MBCT on depressive symptoms, suggesting that strengthening mindfulness may promote recovery in TRD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with Treatment-Resistant Depression (TRD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the need for and strategies to provide additional support for MBCT graduates to maintain long-term benefits and reduce depression relapse.
results_summary: Participants highly valued MBCT but faced challenges maintaining practices post-course, leading to interest in a maintenance program to sustain benefits and reduce relapse risk.
population_specificity: MBCT graduates (n=18) and MBCT teachers (n=16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) for chronically, treatment-resistant depressed patients over a 6-month follow-up period and identify predictors of treatment outcomes.
results_summary: MBCT led to sustained improvements in depressive symptoms, quality of life, rumination, mindfulness skills, and self-compassion over 6 months, with remission rates increasing further during follow-up. Higher baseline rumination predicted better outcomes, while other factors (e.g., duration of depression, treatment resistance, childhood trauma) did not influence results.
population_specificity: Chronically, treatment-resistant depressed outpatients (N = 106).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if practitioner-supported MBCT-SH is superior to CBT-SH in reducing depressive symptom severity and if it is cost-effective for adults with mild to moderate depression.
results_summary: MBCT-SH led to significantly greater reductions in depression symptom severity compared to CBT-SH at 16 weeks, with a between-group difference of -1.5 PHQ-9 points. It was also found to be highly cost-effective, with a probability exceeding 95%.
population_specificity: Adults with mild to moderate depression attending publicly funded psychological therapy services in England.
effective_dosage: Participants received a workbook and 6 support sessions with a trained practitioner.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop clinical prediction models to help adults with recurrent depression choose between maintaining antidepressant medication (ADM) or switching to Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) for relapse prevention.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with the poorest ADM prognoses who switched to MBCT had better outcomes (48% relapse) compared to those who maintained ADM (70% relapse). For those with moderate-to-good ADM prognosis, both treatments resulted in similar relapse likelihood.
population_specificity: Adults with recurrent depression (N=424 from the PREVENT trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize the effect of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) on depression and suicidal ideation in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed significant improvement in depression and suicidal ideation among MDD patients receiving MBCT, suggesting it is relatively convenient and effective for prevention and alleviation. Future research should evaluate long-term effects.
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).
effective_dosage: 1.5-2.5 hours per session, five times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of blended and unguided online mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (eMBCT) versus care as usual (CAU) in reducing psychological distress among cancer patients and survivors.
results_summary: The study found that eMBCT may reduce psychological distress and improve quality of life for cancer patients and survivors, with outcomes measured at multiple follow-up points. Secondary benefits included improvements in fear of cancer recurrence, fatigue, rumination, mindfulness skills, and self-compassion.
population_specificity: Dutch-speaking adult cancer patients or survivors with internet access.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) is effective and cost-effective for depressed patients who did not respond to high-intensity therapy in the IAPT pathway.
results_summary: The study will assess MBCT's impact on depression symptomatology at 10 and 34 weeks post-randomization, comparing it to treatment as usual (TAU), with primary outcomes measured using the PHQ-9. Secondary outcomes include clinical changes and cost-effectiveness evaluations.
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder who did not sufficiently respond to at least 12 sessions of IAPT high-intensity therapy.
study_duration: 10 weeks (intervention period), with follow-up assessments at 34 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a process-based approach using Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) for a case involving problematic substance use and emotional symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that MBCT improved targeted psychological processes and mindfulness traits, leading to significant reductions in substance abuse and emotional symptoms, with gains maintained at 3-month follow-up.
population_specificity: A woman with concomitant problematic substance use and emotional symptoms.
effective_dosage: 8 weeks of individually delivered MBCT sessions (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and pilot a perinatal mental health preventive intervention using Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy to increase access and appeal for preventing perinatal depression.
results_summary: The study describes the adaptation of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy for perinatal depression (Center M) and highlights its potential efficacy in preventing perinatal depression, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract. The intervention addresses barriers in standard prenatal care, particularly for underserved populations.
population_specificity: Pregnant people, with a focus on people of color, those living in rural regions, and those living in poverty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) on depressive symptoms in people with stroke.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed a significant reduction in depressive symptoms for both poststroke participants with and without clinically defined depression, with stronger effects observed in those with depression. However, the impact on physiological disease parameters remains undetermined.
population_specificity: Poststroke patients, including those with and without clinically defined depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a 12-week online mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (eMBCT) on fatigue in patients with sarcoidosis.
results_summary: The study found that eMBCT significantly improved fatigue, anxiety, depression, mindfulness, and general health status compared to the control group, with a mean change in FAS score of -4.53 in the eMBCT group versus -1.28 in the control group.
population_specificity: Adults (18+) with stable sarcoidosis and a Fatigue Assessment Scale (FAS) score >21.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) could effectively augment antidepressants and improve facial emotion recognition in patients with late-life depression (LLD), while also exploring its underlying neural mechanisms.
results_summary: MBCT significantly increased positive affect and improved recognition accuracy and speed for angry and sad faces in LLD patients, with neural changes observed in the left superior temporal gyrus (L-STG). No such improvements were detected in the treatment-as-usual (TAU) group.
population_specificity: Patients with late-life depression (LLD) (n = 60, 30 per group).
effective_dosage: Eight-week MBCT program (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on menopausal symptoms in women who underwent risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy (RRSO), particularly BRCA1/2 carriers.
results_summary: MBSR was associated with indirect increases in the intensity of somatic-vegetative and psychological menopausal symptoms. However, it showed positive direct effects on different menopausal symptoms in multigroup analysis, suggesting mixed outcomes.
population_specificity: Women with BRCA1/2 mutations who underwent RRSO (N = 199, mean age = 50.5 ± 6.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on psychological measures and attentional patterns in individuals with chronic pain.
results_summary: The MBSR program significantly improved depression, anxiety, stress, pain acceptance, well-being, and life satisfaction but had limited impact on attentional patterns, only increasing gaze duration across stimuli.
population_specificity: Thirty-two individuals with chronic pain and no prior mindfulness experience.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on sleep quality and perceived stress in patients with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: MBSR significantly improved sleep quality and reduced perceived stress in SCI patients compared to the control group, with effects becoming more pronounced at 8 weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal cord injury (SCI) diagnosed via imaging and clinical symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) improves workplace well-being and empathy levels among nurses in psychiatric wards.
results_summary: The MBSR group showed significant improvements in workplace well-being, its intrapersonal dimension, empathy, and the perspective-taking subscale compared to the control group, both immediately after the intervention and one month later.
population_specificity: 80 clinical nurses from psychiatric wards at Ibn-e-Sina psychiatric hospital in Iran.
effective_dosage: Eight-week program with weekly two-hour sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the time-varying impact of the MBSR program on stress and mindfulness variables at 3 months, 1 year, and 3 years post-intervention, as well as identify barriers and facilitators in maintaining mindfulness practice.
results_summary: The MBSR program showed significant short-term stress reduction and increased awareness, sustained benefits in inner calm and coping at 1 year, and long-term lifestyle adoption, compassion, and personal growth at 3 years.
population_specificity: 45 participants who completed an 8-week MBSR program at different time points.
study_duration: 8-week program with follow-ups at 3 months, 1 year, and 3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if internet-delivered mindfulness-based stress reduction (IMBSR) was noninferior to internet-delivered cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (ICBT-I) in reducing insomnia severity among nurses.
results_summary: IMBSR significantly reduced insomnia severity and depression but was less effective than ICBT-I, which showed superior results in reducing insomnia severity and depression. Both interventions improved mindfulness, and nurses reported high satisfaction with both.
population_specificity: Nurses with insomnia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of remotely administered group CBT and MBCT in improving symptoms and functioning among adolescents with mood disorders or attenuated psychosis symptoms.
results_summary: Both CBT and MBCT showed comparable improvements in mood, anxiety, attenuated psychosis symptoms, and psychosocial functioning over 5 months. CBT outperformed MBCT in emotion regulation and well-being posttreatment, while MBCT showed greater social functioning improvements in adolescents with higher childhood adversity. Satisfaction was higher for CBT.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 13-17 with mood disorders or attenuated psychosis symptoms.
study_duration: 2 months (with follow-up assessments at posttreatment and 3 months posttreatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction and compassion-focused therapy on reducing digestive symptom severity in IBS patients.
results_summary: Both mindfulness-based stress reduction and compassion-focused therapy were equally effective in reducing the severity of IBS symptoms, with statistically significant results (P<0.01). The effects were maintained through follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) in Isfahan city.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction therapy versus standard care on the quality of life and psychological status of breast cancer patients.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based stress reduction therapy significantly reduced negative emotions (stress, depression, anxiety, fear of recurrence) and improved coping ability and emotional states in breast cancer patients compared to standard care.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction on placental volume and perfusion in pregnant women at high risk for small-for-gestational-age newborns.
results_summary: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction was associated with a lower prevalence of small placental volume (5% vs. 17% in the non-intervention group) and partially mediated (45.3%) the effect on reducing small-for-gestational-age risk. Placental perfusion results were similar across groups.
population_specificity: Pregnant women at high risk for small-for-gestational-age newborns (19- to 23-week gestation).
effective_dosage: 8-week program with weekly 2.5-hour sessions and one full-day session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on stress, anxiety, and depression among nursing students during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR significantly reduced stress, anxiety, and depression scores in nursing students immediately after the intervention and at the 2-month follow-up. The effects were statistically significant (p < 0.001) and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Nursing students at Qom University of Medical Sciences during the COVID-19 pandemic.
study_duration: Not specified (intervention duration not mentioned in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical effectiveness of combining mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) with exercise intervention in improving anxiety, depression, sleep quality, and mood regulation in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
results_summary: The study found that combining MBSR with exercise therapy significantly improved anxiety, depression, sleep quality, and BSRS-5 scores in NSCLC patients compared to conventional psychological nursing care, with notable differences observed at 6 and 8 weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who had not received surgical treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility, acceptability, and adherence of remotely delivered mindfulness-based stress reduction combined with prenatal sleep classes (MBSR+PS) compared to treatment as usual (TAU) in pregnant women with poor sleep quality.
results_summary: The study found high acceptability, feasibility, and adherence rates for MBSR+PS, with 88% initiating treatment and 92% retention. Exploratory outcomes suggested improved sleep efficiency in the MBSR+PS group compared to TAU (SMD=.68).
population_specificity: Pregnant women with poor sleep quality (n=52).
effective_dosage: MBSR: eight weekly 2.5-hour sessions; PS: eight weekly 30-minute sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) in reducing stress-related subscales (e.g., burnout, workload, conflicts) among nurses in geriatric centers.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in the intervention group across multiple stress-related subscales, including death and dying, conflicts with physicians, inadequate preparation, lack of support resources, conflicts with nurses, workload, and uncertainty of treatment, as well as burnout scores.
population_specificity: 60 nurses from three geriatric centers.
effective_dosage: Eight training sessions (specific duration per session not mentioned).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (implied by eight sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) and other mind-body medicine techniques on blood pressure in patients with cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that MBSR and similar interventions significantly improved systolic blood pressure but had no significant effect on diastolic blood pressure. High heterogeneity and low study quality suggest the need for more robust evidence.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify key questions, barriers, facilitators, and priority evidence needed to inform health insurance coverage decisions for Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) in the United States.
results_summary: The study found that the most highly rated factors for MBSR coverage included research demonstrating its effectiveness and safety, while barriers included its non-medical treatment status and patient attendance issues. Facilitators included MBSR's potential to address mental health and psychosomatic problems, and the highest priority evidence needed was understanding which conditions MBSR effectively treats and its impact on stress.
population_specificity: Key informants (n=26) including health insurers, healthcare administrators, policymakers, clinicians, MBSR instructors, and MBSR students.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of combining Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) with nonconvulsive electrotherapy (NET) on depression and analyze changes in serum inflammatory factors.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR combined with NET significantly improved depression symptoms, reduced suicidal thoughts, enhanced sleep quality, lowered inflammatory markers (IL-2, IL-1β, IL-6), and improved quality of life compared to MBSR alone.
population_specificity: 140 patients undergoing treatment for depression between May 2017 and June 2022.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of WeChat-based mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on psychological resilience and quality of life in patients undergoing loose body removal surgery.
results_summary: The study found that WeChat-based MBSR significantly reduced depression and anxiety, improved mindfulness, quality of life, personality traits, and psychological resilience compared to routine postoperative nursing.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing surgical treatment for loose body removal (n=87).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of virtual mindfulness-based stress reduction (v-MBSR) for adults with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) experiencing anxiety or depression.
results_summary: The study found that v-MBSR led to decreased anxiety and depression symptoms and improved health-related quality of life, with effects persisting at 6-month follow-up. Participants reported improved coping strategies and disease management, though adherence was low due to time constraints.
population_specificity: Adults with IBD and self-reported anxiety or depression in Alberta, Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the qualitative impact of preoperative Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on the experiences of patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: Participants reported improved relaxation, confidence, and coping during the preoperative period, with others noticing positive changes post-MBSR. Motivations for participation included surgical preparation and learning new coping strategies, with strong commitment to the intervention noted.
population_specificity: 10 patients scheduled for total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on sympathetic nervous system (SNS) activity in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that MBSR significantly reduced sympathetic reactivity during mental stress in CKD patients, while the Health Education Program (HEP) showed no change. The results suggest MBSR may have clinically beneficial effects on autonomic function in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with CKD stages III-IV (63 ±9 years; 86% males).

study_goal: To assess the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on structural and functional outcomes in patients with central serous chorioretinopathy (CSCR).
results_summary: MBSR showed statistically significant improvements in best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central macular thickness (CMT) at 1, 3, and 6 months compared to the control group, suggesting faster resolution of subretinal fluid and enhanced BCVA.
population_specificity: 60 patients with central serous chorioretinopathy (CSCR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on fibromyalgia patients and identify the role of pain cognitions (PIPS and PCS) as mechanisms of change.
results_summary: MBSR showed significant improvements in fibromyalgia symptoms, perceived stress, and depression compared to the waitlist control, with effects mediated by changes in pain-related cognitions (PIPS and PCS). Improvements in stress and depression remained stable over six months.
population_specificity: 95 fibromyalgia patients (mean age 49.18 ± 13.26 years).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but measurements were taken pre-intervention, post-intervention, and at 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on mental health and quality of life in CKD patients with mild-to-moderate depression.
results_summary: MBSR significantly improved mental health, sleep quality, and quality of life in CKD patients, as evidenced by lower SDS and PSQI scores and higher CD-RISC, FFMQ, and SF-36 scores compared to conventional management.
population_specificity: CKD patients with mild-to-moderate depression treated at Jiading District Central Hospital Affiliated Shanghai University of Medicine & Health Sciences.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction and compassion-focused therapy on cognitive emotion regulation in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: Both mindfulness-based stress reduction and compassion-focused therapy were effective in improving cognitive regulation of adaptive emotion, but compassion-focused therapy showed a greater improvement in mean scores compared to mindfulness-based stress reduction.
population_specificity: Patients with IBS in Isfahan city.
study_duration: Not specified beyond the number of sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) could improve psychological outcomes (stress, anxiety, depression, quality of life) and cognitive metrics in older individuals with HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND).
results_summary: MBSR significantly improved symptoms of depression at 8 weeks (though not sustained at 16 weeks) and perceived quality of life at 16 weeks compared to the waitlist control. Cognitive performance did not differ between groups.
population_specificity: Adults aged 55+ with HIV and cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on psychosomatic stress-related outcomes and quality of life among university students through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: MBSR significantly reduced anxiety, depression, and perceived stress while improving mindfulness, self-kindness, and physical health. No significant effects were observed for sleep quality, social function, or subjective well-being.
population_specificity: University students

study_goal: To explore the effects of online mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on anxiety, depression, and quality of life in caregivers of patients with severe mental disorders.
results_summary: Online MBSR significantly reduced anxiety and depression scores and improved quality of life (except physiological function) in caregivers compared to the control group, which showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Caregivers of patients with schizophrenia or bipolar disorder hospitalized in Yunnan Provincial Mental Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on emotion regulation and sleep problems in depressed elderly individuals.
results_summary: The MBSR intervention significantly reduced depression symptoms and improved emotion regulation and sleep quality in the elderly participants with depression compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with depression, referred by geriatricians.
effective_dosage: 8 sessions of 90 minutes each, once a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) and deep relaxation exercises on pregnancy-related anxiety levels.
results_summary: The MBSR program significantly reduced pregnancy-related anxiety, including fears of giving birth, worries about bearing a handicapped child, and concerns about appearance, compared to deep relaxation exercises and routine prenatal care. Deep relaxation exercises also reduced fear of giving birth but were less effective than MBSR for other anxiety measures.
population_specificity: 95 pregnant women from outpatient clinics in the Southeastern Anatolia Region of Türkiye.
effective_dosage: MBSR group: eight sessions (two per week for 4 weeks); deep relaxation group: exercises at home four times a week for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors and moderators of treatment response to Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) and other psychosocial interventions for chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that low cognitive/behavioral function, favorable treatment expectations, and sound working alliances predicted better outcomes across treatments, including MBSR. Women benefited more than men, and high cognitive/behavioral function predicted favorable outcomes only in the treatment-as-usual condition.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic low back pain (N = 521).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a modified telehealth MBSR program could improve mindfulness and reduce depression, anxiety, and emotion regulation difficulties in adults with cerebral palsy and elevated anxiety/emotional regulation issues.
results_summary: The study found no significant between-group difference in mindfulness (primary outcome), but the MBSR group showed improvements in depression, stress, and emotion regulation scores over time.
population_specificity: Adults with cerebral palsy, elevated anxiety/emotional regulation difficulties, and no/mild intellectual impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) compared to a health promotion program in older Portuguese-speaking migrants, focusing on outcomes like executive functioning, stress, and well-being.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a rigorous comparison of MBSR against an active control, but results are not yet reported as it is a protocol paper. The design suggests potential efficacy based on prior MBSR studies.
population_specificity: Older Portuguese-speaking migrants aged ≥55.
effective_dosage: 8-week program with weekly meetings, one 4-hour class, and at-home tasks.
study_duration: 8 weeks, with follow-up assessments up to 3 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) reduces proinflammatory gene expression and systemic inflammation markers in lonely older adults.
results_summary: MBSR reduced proinflammatory gene regulation (NF-κB) but did not significantly affect other transcription factors (CREB, IRF, GR) or circulating inflammatory markers (IL-6, CRP) compared to the control intervention.
population_specificity: Lonely older adults aged 65-85 years (N = 190).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether MBSR-related improvements in asthma control are linked to changes in salience network function and inflammatory biomarkers.
results_summary: The MBSR group showed increased functional connectivity within the salience network, which correlated with improved asthma control and reduced inflammatory biomarkers. These changes were associated with enhanced attention control and emotion regulation.
population_specificity: Adults with asthma
effective_dosage: 8 weeks of MBSR (specific dosage not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) with other therapies (DBT, ACT) and a control group on IBS symptoms, quality of life, anxiety, and depression in IBS patients.
results_summary: MBSR showed significant improvements in IBS symptoms, quality of life, anxiety, and depression compared to the control group, though ACT demonstrated superior outcomes in these measures. The study noted limitations such as lack of follow-up and restricted applicability to other populations.
population_specificity: 83 patients (54 male, 29 female) with Rome-IV diagnosed irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on patient-relevant outcomes (migraine frequency, headache intensity, depressive symptoms, and quality of life) in adult migraine patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no statistically significant benefit of MBSR for migraine frequency but showed a significant reduction in depressive symptoms. The evidence base was deemed insufficient for definitive recommendations.
population_specificity: Adult patients with migraine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction counseling on blood sugar levels and perceived stress in women with gestational diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction significantly reduced fasting blood sugar, 2-hour fasting blood sugar, and perceived stress scores in women with gestational diabetes compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Women with gestational diabetes (mean age ~28-29 years).
effective_dosage: 8 sessions of 90 minutes each, conducted twice a week.
study_duration: 4 weeks (assuming twice a week for 8 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based stress reduction during pregnancy is associated with differences in fetal and neonatal brain development compared to usual care.
results_summary: Offspring from the stress reduction group showed larger fetal left anterior cingulate gyri volume and higher scores in the Neonatal Neurobehavioral Assessment Scale for regulation of state compared to the usual care group.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with singleton pregnancies in Barcelona, Spain.
effective_dosage: 8-week mindfulness-based stress reduction program adapted for pregnancy (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pleiotropic beneficial effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction on cardiovascular and cancer risk factors, quality of life, sleep quality, and immune function in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction reduced cancer-related fatigue and stress, improved quality of life, and positively influenced immune function and cardiometabolic risk factors, including inflammatory biomarkers. However, the review noted limited clinical studies available in the literature.
population_specificity: Cancer patients in different stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an adapted Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) program in improving mental wellbeing and reducing stress, anxiety, and depression in a psychosocially vulnerable group of pregnant women.
results_summary: The study protocol suggests that MBSR is a promising non-pharmacological intervention for reducing stress and improving mental health in pregnant women, with potential benefits for maternal antenatal attachment, childbirth experience, and transition to parenthood. Results from meta-analyses cited in the abstract consistently indicate reductions in symptoms of stress, anxiety, and depression.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with a preconception history of mental disorders or psychosocial vulnerabilities (n=240) recruited from an obstetric ambulatory clinic in Denmark.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the U.S. general public's knowledge, attitudes, barriers, and preferences regarding Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) for chronic pain management, particularly in community pharmacy settings.
results_summary: The study found low self-rated knowledge and confidence in MBSR among respondents, with positive general beliefs about MBSR for chronic pain but negative perceptions of pharmacy-delivered MBSR. Confidence in seeking MBSR and current opioid use were positively associated with beliefs about pharmacy-delivered MBSR, while income and pain level had negative associations.
population_specificity: U.S. adults aged ≥18 years, predominantly white (79.1%) and female (50.7%), with a mean age of 44.65 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a structured stress reduction program during pregnancy could influence fetal-infant neurodevelopment compared to usual care.
results_summary: The stress reduction group showed deeper insula measurements and lower rates of suboptimal scores in the ASQ fine motor domain compared to the usual care group, suggesting potential benefits for neurodevelopment.
population_specificity: Singleton pregnancies at high risk for small-for-gestational age.
study_duration: Intervention began at 19-23 weeks' gestation, with follow-up until 1 year of corrected age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) program on stress levels and salivary cortisol in substance abuse patients.
results_summary: The MBSR program significantly reduced stress levels (p < 0.05) and salivary cortisol (mean reduction of 10.54, p < 0.005) in the experimental group compared to the control group, which showed no significant change (p > 0.005).
population_specificity: 60 drug addicts receiving treatment at an addiction center, divided into experimental (n=30) and control (n=30) groups.
effective_dosage: Two 1-hour sessions per day, capped at 15 participants per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) program during pregnancy improves child neurodevelopmental outcomes at age 2 years.
results_summary: The study found that children from the MBSR group had significantly higher scores in the social-emotional domain compared to the usual care group, indicating a positive effect of MBSR on this aspect of neurodevelopment. No significant differences were observed in other domains.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals (19-23 weeks' gestation) at high risk of delivering newborns small for gestational age.
effective_dosage: 8-week MBSR program adapted for pregnancy (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an online mindfulness-based stress reduction intervention could improve subjective well-being, reduce job burnout, and enhance psychological adaptation in postpandemic-era nurses.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved nurses' positive emotions, life satisfaction, and psychological adaptation while reducing negative emotions, low personal accomplishment, and job burnout compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Postpandemic-era nurses (90 participants, split into intervention and control groups).
effective_dosage: Weekly online mindfulness-based stress reduction training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of mindfulness-based stress reduction versus psychoeducation and support in reducing parenting stress among parents of preschool-aged autistic children.
results_summary: Both interventions significantly reduced parenting stress, but mindfulness-based stress reduction was more effective, with the strongest effects observed at the 12-month follow-up, suggesting lasting and potentially increasing benefits over time.
population_specificity: Parents of preschool-aged autistic children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an online MBSR intervention in alleviating anxiety and depression among asymptomatic/mild COVID-19 patients under quarantine.
results_summary: The online MBSR program significantly reduced anxiety and depression scores compared to the control group, with the proportion of severe cases dropping to 0% in the MBSR group. The intervention also increased the proportion of patients with mild symptoms compared to controls.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic/mild COVID-19 patients treated in Sanya Fangcang hospital under quarantine restrictions.
effective_dosage: Daily sessions for 5 days (specific duration per session not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an 8-week MBSR program was feasible and acceptable for pre-symptomatic Huntington's disease patients and whether it improved mindfulness skills and psychological adjustment.
results_summary: The program showed feasibility and acceptability, with improved mindfulness skills (observing and non-judgment) and qualitative benefits like reduced ruminations and isolation. Quantitative psychological adjustment remained stable post-treatment.
population_specificity: Pre-symptomatic Huntington's disease patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a culturally adapted MBSR program on self-report and neuroimaging outcomes for Chinese adults with chronic pain.
results_summary: The MBSR group showed significant reductions in pain catastrophizing post-treatment, though the effect was not maintained at follow-up. Completer analyses also found improvements in pain interference and perceived stress, but not other measures. Neuroimaging revealed unique changes in regional homogeneity for the MBSR group.
population_specificity: Chinese adults with chronic pain

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on stress regulation in university students with elevated stress levels, investigate its neural mechanisms, and identify factors influencing treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR reduced perceived stress and improved stress resilience, with additional benefits on depressive and anxiety symptoms, positive mental health, and stress reactivity in daily life. Potential mediating and moderating factors were also examined to understand individual differences in treatment response.
population_specificity: Dutch university students with mild to high self-reported stress levels.
study_duration: Not specified (measured at baseline, post-treatment, and three months after training)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mediating effects of self-reported altered resting state of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on mental health outcomes when provided as a universal intervention in a real-life context.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant mediated effects of altered resting state (measured by ARSQ subscales) on perceived stress, anxiety, depression, and well-being, suggesting MBSR can reduce mind wandering and increase comfort. No significant mediating effects were found for Theory of Mind, Self, or Somatic Awareness subscales.
population_specificity: 191 schoolteachers from 110 schools across five geographical regions in Denmark.
effective_dosage: Standardized MBSR (specific dosage not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: 6 months (data collected at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on hemodynamic parameters, psychosocial characteristics, quality of life, and cardiovascular outcomes in patients with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) after primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PPCI).
results_summary: The MBSR group showed improvements in blood pressure, lower anxiety and perceived stress scores, higher perceived social support, better health-related quality of life, and a significantly lower rate of major adverse cardiovascular events compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) who underwent successful primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PPCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) program in reducing premenstrual symptoms compared to a control group.
results_summary: The MBSR group showed significantly lower PMS symptoms post-intervention compared to the control group, with a large effect size. All specific symptoms measured by PMSS subscales also showed significant reductions in the MBSR group.
population_specificity: University students (women aged 20-30) with PMS (PMSS score ≥45).
effective_dosage: 8 weekly sessions (2.5 hours each) and a 6-hour silence retreat during week 6.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) with early cardiac rehabilitation (CR) improves psychological and cardiac outcomes in acute myocardial infarction (AMI) patients with intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) assistance.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR combined with CR significantly reduced anxiety, depression, and negative mood states, decreased IABP-related complications, and improved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) more than CR alone.
population_specificity: AMI patients with IABP assistance due to hemodynamic instability (n=100).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mindfulness meditation on blood pressure, mental health, and quality of life in patients with hypertension.
results_summary: The 12-week MBSR program significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure and improved mental health (stress, anxiety, depression) and quality of life compared to routine care.
population_specificity: Eighty adult women with Stage I or II hypertension in Isfahan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the psychological health of patients with chronic diseases during COVID-19 and examine the efficacy and feasibility of MBSR intervention.
results_summary: The MBSR intervention improved psychological distress and reduced mean scores of depression, anxiety, and stress. The program was found feasible and effective for chronic disease patients, showing positive impacts on negative psychological stress domains.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic diseases recruited from university hospital outpatient clinics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) could be adapted for autistic adults and whether participants found it beneficial for stress reduction and coping.
results_summary: Participants reported that MBSR could lower stress symptoms and improve stress coping, and they were positive about the intervention, recommending it to others. However, larger studies are needed to further investigate these effects.
population_specificity: 50 autistic adults without intellectual disability

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of low-dose oral minoxidil, topical minoxidil, and PRP combined with topical minoxidil in treating androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: At 32 weeks, oral minoxidil and PRP with topical minoxidil showed a 25% improvement in AGA severity, while topical minoxidil alone showed 10%. PRP with topical minoxidil had the highest increase in terminal hair density (57%), and oral minoxidil showed the greatest reduction in vellus hair density (26%). Side effects were mild and tolerable across all groups.
population_specificity: 75 participants with androgenetic alopecia, randomly assigned to three treatment groups (n=25 each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical therapeutic effects of microneedling plus 5% Minoxidil and Finasteride versus monotherapy or dual therapy in treating male androgenetic alopecia.
