results_summary: The study found that combination therapy (microneedling, 5% Minoxidil, and Finasteride) significantly improved hair density, hair shaft diameter, and Norwood-Hamilton alopecia scale compared to monotherapy or dual therapy, with 80% of patients in the combination group showing notable improvement. Adverse reactions did not differ significantly among groups.
population_specificity: 45 male patients with androgenetic alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of oral minoxidil on the frontotemporal hairline in patients with frontal fibrosing alopecia (FFA).
results_summary: Subjective improvement in frontotemporal hairline density was observed in 45.1% of patients, with mild, moderate, and excellent responses. Hair density improved in 57.4% of patients' interparietal region, and eyebrow/eyelash growth occurred in 25.4% and 3.3% of patients, respectively. Adverse effects were reported in 33.6% of patients, most commonly hypertrichosis (23.8%).
population_specificity: Patients with frontal fibrosing alopecia (FFA) from 2 Brazilian and 1 Spanish centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare adherence, satisfaction, and side effects between topical and oral minoxidil for hair loss treatment.
results_summary: Oral minoxidil showed greater ease of use, adherence, and satisfaction compared to topical minoxidil, with similar side effects except for higher hypertrichosis incidence in oral users.
population_specificity: Patients using minoxidil (n=50, response rate 98.0%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) in treating short anagen hair syndrome (SAS) in an adult patient.
results_summary: The patient experienced reduced hair shedding, increased hair length, and improved hair density after LDOM treatment, confirmed by objective measurements. Mild facial hypertrichosis was reported but did not deter treatment continuation.
population_specificity: A 24-year-old female with persistent short anagen hair syndrome (SAS).
effective_dosage: Started at 1.25 mg, increased to 2.5 mg after one month.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but follow-up occurred after dose adjustment (implied short-term).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a modified MBSR program could reduce psychological (stress and depression) and physiological (cortisol and creatine kinase) stress markers compared to an active control condition.
results_summary: The MBSR intervention significantly reduced symptoms of stress and depression more than the active control, with large effect sizes. It also led to greater decreases in cortisol and creatine kinase concentrations compared to the control.
population_specificity: Male wrestlers (average age 26.73 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of oral minoxidil on hair and nail growth rates in healthy adult men.
results_summary: Minoxidil 2.5 mg/day increased nail growth speed by 50.7%, while both 1 mg/day and 2.5 mg/day increased hair growth speed by 16.5% and 35.9%, respectively. Heart rate increased with both dosages, but no changes in blood pressure or other adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 10 healthy adult men aged 21 to 46 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term topical use of minoxidil could lead to Cutis verticis gyrata (CVG) as a side effect.
results_summary: The study reported a case of CVG resulting from long-term topical minoxidil use, suggesting a potential link between minoxidil and IGF-1-mediated soft tissue hypertrophy. This is the first documented case of secondary CVG from topical minoxidil use.
population_specificity: A single case of a male with androgenetic alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether botanical extracts combined with minoxidil could improve hair growth in a patient with Hypotrichosis simplex of the scalp (HSS).
results_summary: The study found that combining botanical extracts with minoxidil resulted in significant hair growth after two treatments in an 8-year-old male with HSS. This suggests the combination may be a potential therapeutic approach for HSS.
population_specificity: 8-year-old male child diagnosed with HSS caused by a mutation in CDSN.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety profile and incidence of side effects of low-dose oral minoxidil in male patients with androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: The study found that low-dose oral minoxidil had a good safety profile, with hypertrichosis being the most common side effect. Systemic side effects were infrequent, and no life-threatening adverse effects were observed.
population_specificity: 100 male patients with androgenetic alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and side effect profiles of minoxidil (MD) with other pharmacological treatments for anal fissures (AF).
results_summary: Minoxidil demonstrated a moderate healing rate, ranking third after nifedipine and diltiazem, and had a relatively low incidence of adverse effects, second only to lidocaine. However, it was less effective in pain reduction compared to diltiazem.
population_specificity: Patients with anal fissures (total of 1770 participants across 22 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of using a pharmaceutical 3D printer to prepare Minoxidil capsules in a community pharmacy setting, comparing it to conventional manual capsule filling.
results_summary: The 3D-printed Minoxidil capsules met European Pharmacopeia standards for mass uniformity, drug content, and dissolution, and demonstrated stability for three months. The 3D printing method was more precise, efficient, and reduced operator involvement by over half compared to manual filling.
population_specificity: 9 patients in a community compounding pharmacy setting in Spain.

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of combined fractional CO2 laser with topical minoxidil 5% solution versus topical minoxidil 5% solution alone in treating alopecia areata.
results_summary: The combination group showed 80% excellent improvement, while the minoxidil-only group showed 53% excellent improvement. Both treatments were significantly better than placebo, with minimal and transient side effects.
population_specificity: 150 patients with alopecia areata from outpatient clinics of the Dermatology and Venerology Department, Tanta University Hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-dose sub-lingual minoxidil (SLM) increases hair fibre diameter in men with male androgenetic alopecia (MAGA), as a proxy for reversing hair follicle miniaturization.
results_summary: The study found that SLM increased hair fibre diameter in a dose-dependent manner, with significant effects observed at 1.35mg and 4.05mg doses but not at 0.45mg. The increase was most pronounced in intermediate and thickest hairs, suggesting reversal of follicle miniaturization.
population_specificity: 33 men with MAGA in the initial trial, plus 12 additional participants in an extension study.
study_duration: 24 weeks for the initial trial, plus a 6-month open-label extension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance minoxidil delivery into hair follicles using nanocrystals (MG-MXD@NP) and compare its hair growth efficacy to a conventional minoxidil lotion.
results_summary: MG-MXD@NP improved minoxidil delivery to skin tissue, hair bulges, and bulbs, resulting in earlier and superior hair growth compared to a commercial lotion. Elevated expression of hair follicle stem cell markers (CD34, CD200) suggested activation of cells linked to hair growth enhancement.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the morphological and cytotoxic effects of minoxidil on Phaseolus vulgaris L as a bioindicator for potential ecotoxicological impacts.
results_summary: High concentrations of minoxidil (2.5-5 mg/L) significantly inhibited germination (75-76%) and root growth (52.6-55.3%), decreased the mitotic index (8.2), and increased chromosomal abnormalities (10.2), indicating cytotoxic effects. The study suggests minoxidil can adversely affect plant morphology and cell division even at low concentrations.
population_specificity: Phaseolus vulgaris L (common bean) seeds

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of monotherapy with topical or oral minoxidil in treating alopecia areata.
results_summary: The study found that 5% topical minoxidil had an 82% response rate, while lower concentrations had a 58% response rate; oral minoxidil also showed an 82% response rate. Minoxidil, both topical and oral, may be beneficial for alopecia areata, but insufficient data exist to recommend it as a first-line treatment.
population_specificity: 372 patients with alopecia areata (338 using topical minoxidil, 34 taking oral minoxidil).
effective_dosage: 5% topical minoxidil, less than 5% topical minoxidil, and oral minoxidil (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Mean treatment duration was 27 weeks (range: 2-60 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of severe hypertrichosis in a woman using topical 5% minoxidil and its resolution after discontinuation.
results_summary: The study found that topical 5% minoxidil can cause severe hypertrichosis, which resolved spontaneously three months after stopping treatment. It also noted that side effects like irritant dermatitis and pruritus are more common with 5% solutions than 2%.
population_specificity: A 24-year-old woman with androgenic alopecia.
study_duration: Duration of use not specified, but hypertrichosis resolved three months after discontinuation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of injectable minoxidil for treating androgenetic alopecia and alopecia areata.
results_summary: Injectable minoxidil showed significant improvement in hair growth for androgenetic alopecia, while results for alopecia areata were mixed. Primary side effects included hypotension and pain.
population_specificity: Patients of all age groups and genders with androgenetic alopecia or alopecia areata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of microneedling, minoxidil, and platelet-rich plasma treatments for androgenetic alopecia in men.
results_summary: Group B (microneedling + 5% minoxidil) showed increased hair number and density, but only group C (platelet-rich plasma) demonstrated a statistically significant increase in hair shaft thickness.
population_specificity: 92 men aged 20-50 years with androgenetic alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review minoxidil's pharmacological properties, mechanisms of action, clinical effectiveness, side effects, and emerging applications in dermatology.
results_summary: The study found minoxidil effective for promoting hair growth, particularly in androgenetic alopecia, and highlighted its potential in alopecia areata, combination therapies, scar treatment, and wound healing. Side effects and safety profiles were discussed, but the precise mechanism of action remains unclear.
population_specificity: General dermatological applications (no specific population mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of minoxidil spray versus HUCB-MSC therapy in reversing hair loss in testosterone-induced androgenic alopecia in rats.
results_summary: Minoxidil showed temporary efficacy but resulted in significant hair loss after 37 days, while HUCB-MSC therapy demonstrated sustained hair regrowth and structural improvements.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar albino rats (3 months old) with testosterone-induced androgenic alopecia.
effective_dosage: Daily minoxidil spray (specific concentration not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and safety of combining microneedling with topical 5% minoxidil for treating androgenetic alopecia (AGA).
results_summary: The combination therapy significantly increased hair density (95.6 vs. 52.4 hair/cm²) and diameter (18 vs. 6 μm) compared to minoxidil alone, with side effects like itching and transient erythema being well tolerated.
population_specificity: 36 male participants aged 26-51 with Hamilton-Norwood type III-VI AGA.

study_goal: To create an expert consensus statement for low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) prescribing for patients with hair loss, addressing safety, efficacy, and clinical guidelines.
results_summary: The study achieved consensus on 76 items, including diagnoses benefiting from LDOM, dosing for adults and adolescents, contraindications, and monitoring. Pediatric use and titration protocols did not reach consensus.
population_specificity: Patients with hair loss, including adults (18+) and adolescents (12-17); pediatric patients (<12) were underrepresented.
effective_dosage: Dosing for adults and adolescents (12-17) was specified, but exact amounts are not detailed in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential hypotensive effects of low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) in patients using it for alopecia treatment.
results_summary: LDOM did not significantly alter systolic or diastolic blood pressure but showed a tendency toward decreased mean arterial pressure. A significant increase in heart rate was observed, and hypertrichosis was the most frequent side effect, leading to discontinuations in some cases.
population_specificity: Patients using LDOM for alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel topical co-delivery system (M + F@ICPG) combining minoxidil and finasteride to enhance transdermal delivery, hair follicle targeting, and therapeutic efficacy for androgenic alopecia while minimizing adverse effects.
results_summary: M + F@ICPG significantly improved skin penetration and retention of minoxidil and finasteride, enhanced hair follicle targeting, and demonstrated superior hair regeneration, anagen recovery, inflammation mitigation, and microvessel reconstruction in an AGA mouse model. The mechanism involved upregulation of hair growth genes and downregulation of hair loss genes.
population_specificity: AGA mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the compatibility and stability of minoxidil in TrichoSol™ and TrichoFoam™ vehicles for personalized alopecia treatments.
results_summary: The study found that minoxidil formulations in TrichoSol™ and TrichoFoam™ remained chemically stable for up to 180 days with ≤10% degradation, showed no physical alterations, and maintained microbiological efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied general alopecia patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document the effects and treatment of minoxidil toxicosis in a cat after accidental exposure.
results_summary: The cat exhibited severe toxicity symptoms (respiratory distress, hypothermia, hypotension) and required hemodialysis for recovery, ultimately achieving full recovery after 11 days.
population_specificity: A 5-year-old castrated male American Shorthair cat.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of topical finasteride 0.25% combined with minoxidil 5% versus minoxidil 5% alone in treating male pattern androgenic alopecia.
results_summary: The combination of topical finasteride 0.25% and minoxidil 5% showed significantly higher efficacy (86.7%) compared to minoxidil 5% alone (69.1%). The findings support the combination therapy as a superior treatment option for androgenic alopecia.
population_specificity: 164 male patients aged 30-60 years with androgenic alopecia lasting more than 2 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the benefits and potential risks of oral minoxidil versus topical minoxidil therapy in patients with androgenetic alopecia (AGA).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in hair density or diameter between oral and topical minoxidil, but oral minoxidil had a higher incidence of hypertrichosis. Both forms showed similar efficacy and safety profiles, with no significant difference in hypotension incidence.
population_specificity: Patients with androgenetic alopecia (AGA).

study_goal: To compare the safety and efficacy of topical 17α-ethinylestradiol 0.01% combined with minoxidil 2% versus minoxidil 2% alone in treating female pattern hair loss (FPHL).
results_summary: Both treatment groups showed improvement, but the combination of 17α-ethinylestradiol and minoxidil did not offer a statistically significant advantage over minoxidil alone. The combination group experienced more menstrual irregularities.
population_specificity: Forty-three women with female pattern hair loss (FPHL).
effective_dosage: Minoxidil 2% applied twice daily (six puffs per application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a sensitive, affordable, and eco-friendly spectrofluorimetric method for assessing minoxidil and timolol in pharmaceutical formulations and artificial aqueous humor.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a highly sensitive method for detecting minoxidil, with a linear range of 0.20-5.0 µg/mL and a limit of quantification (LOQ) of 0.16 µg/mL. The method demonstrated high accuracy (%recoveries 99.00-101.94%) and low variability (RSD < 2%).
population_specificity: Pharmaceutical formulations and artificial aqueous humor (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) combined with spironolactone versus LDOM combined with finasteride/dutasteride in women with androgenetic alopecia (AGA).
results_summary: Both combination therapies showed similar improvements in hair growth and comparable safety profiles, though the LDOM with finasteride/dutasteride group had a greater (but statistically insignificant) increase in hair width and density. The results support using LDOM with either spironolactone or finasteride/dutasteride for female AGA.
population_specificity: Women with androgenetic alopecia (AGA).

study_goal: To evaluate whether low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) is associated with an increased prevalence of pericardial effusions in patients with alopecia.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the prevalence of small pericardial effusions between LDOM patients (5.8%) and control patients (6%), with none being symptomatic. The results suggest LDOM does not increase pericardial effusion risk in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with alopecia (51 on LDOM, 49 controls).
effective_dosage: Low-dose oral minoxidil (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of compound glycyrrhizin (CG) combined with topical minoxidil therapy compared to topical minoxidil therapy alone in treating alopecia areata (AA).
results_summary: The study found that CG combined with topical minoxidil therapy significantly improved clinical efficacy, reduced SALT scores and inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-12, IFN-γ), and increased TGF-β1 levels, with no significant differences in adverse events between the two groups.
population_specificity: 1189 patients with alopecia areata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the severe adverse effects of minoxidil ingestion, particularly focusing on circulatory shock and pulmonary edema.
results_summary: The study found that unintentional ingestion of topical minoxidil can lead to severe circulatory shock and acute pulmonary edema, requiring aggressive treatment with fluid resuscitation and vasopressors. Midodrine was noted to potentially reduce ICU stay by shortening IV vasopressor usage.
population_specificity: A young female with unintentional minoxidil ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if platelet-rich plasma (PRP) combined with Minoxidil offers better outcomes than Minoxidil alone for treating androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: The study found that PRP plus Minoxidil significantly improved hair density at 1, 3, and 5/6 months compared to Minoxidil alone, with comparable adverse event risks. However, the evidence quality was low to very low due to high bias risk and heterogeneity in PRP preparation.
population_specificity: Patients with androgenetic alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of combining botulinum toxin type A (BTA) with topical 5% Minoxidil compared to Minoxidil alone in treating androgenetic alopecia (AGA) in men.
results_summary: The study found that combining BTA with Minoxidil significantly improved hair growth, scalp conditions, and quality of life at 4 and 6 months compared to Minoxidil alone, with no adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: 60 male patients with androgenetic alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare hypertrichosis rates in female alopecia patients on low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) monotherapy versus combination therapy with spironolactone.
results_summary: Hypertrichosis developed in 33.3% of patients, with lower rates in the combination group (17.6%) compared to monotherapy (40.5%). The trend suggests spironolactone may mitigate LDOM-induced hypertrichosis, though results were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Female alopecia patients (n=54) at NYU Langone Health.
effective_dosage: Low-dose oral minoxidil (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a novel Minoxidil Pickering emulsion gel for targeted delivery to hair follicles to enhance hair regrowth in androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: The study found that the fabricated Minoxidil Pickering emulsion gels improved hair regrowth and targeted hair follicles effectively, with therapeutic effects linked to upregulated hair growth factor expression. The formulation demonstrated enhanced stability and rheological properties due to the use of natural polysaccharides.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied to be individuals with androgenetic alopecia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of oral minoxidil on late alopecia in women who developed hair loss after chemotherapy and/or endocrine therapy.
results_summary: Oral minoxidil improved hair regrowth in 74% of patients, with statistically significant increases in frontal and occipital hair shaft density. No patients discontinued treatment due to adverse events.
population_specificity: Women (mean age 57.8) with late alopecia following chemotherapy and/or endocrine therapy, primarily breast cancer patients (79.1%).
study_duration: Median of 105 days (IQR = 70) for clinical assessments, 91 days (IQR = 126) for trichoscopic assessments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the treatment response and safety of low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) in patients with androgenetic alopecia (AGA) alone versus those with AGA unmasked by telogen effluvium.
results_summary: The study found that LDOM is effective and safe for both groups, with comparable efficacy and safety profiles, supporting its use as a reliable treatment option for AGA.
population_specificity: Patients with androgenetic alopecia (AGA) alone and those with AGA unmasked by telogen effluvium.
effective_dosage: Low-dose oral minoxidil (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the site of action and physiological mechanisms underlying therapeutic responses to oral minoxidil in patients with androgenetic alopecia (AGA).
results_summary: After 6 months of low-dose oral minoxidil treatment, 63.4% of patients experienced clinical improvement, with higher response rates in men (73.1%) than women (40.0%). Patients with low hair follicle sulfotransferase (SULT) activity showed a significantly higher response rate (85%) compared to those with high enzyme activity (43%).
population_specificity: 41 patients with androgenetic alopecia (26 men, 15 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of systemic side effects in a patient using topical minoxidil for hair growth.
results_summary: The study found that excessive topical minoxidil use led to cardiovascular systemic side effects, including dizziness and fatigue, which resolved upon discontinuation. No other causes for the symptoms were identified.
population_specificity: 23-year-old man with androgenetic alopecia or similar hair loss condition.
effective_dosage: Large amounts (exact dosage not specified), applied for three consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of intralesional PRP therapy with topical minoxidil in treating alopecia areata.
results_summary: Minoxidil showed initial effects similar to PRP at one month, but by two and four months, PRP demonstrated significantly better outcomes in reducing SALT scores.
population_specificity: 40 patients (31 males, 9 females) with alopecia areata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of botanical extracts combined with Minoxidil for treating hair loss in a child with hidrotic ectodermal dysplasia 2 (HED2).
results_summary: After one and a half months of treatment, the patient showed remarkable hair growth, suggesting the combination was effective. The study concluded that this approach could be a safe and effective treatment for congenital alopecia in children.
population_specificity: A 6-year-old male child with HED2 caused by GJB6 (p.G11R) mutations, presenting with diffuse thinning, brittle hair, and abnormal nail and tooth development.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a novel transdermal delivery method for minoxidil using β-cyclodextrin encapsulation and photoacoustic waves to improve treatment compliance and reduce adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that photoacoustic waves increased minoxidil transdermal delivery flux by 3-fold, achieving similar efficacy to a 2% commercial formulation with a 1% formulation. In vivo studies showed 86% hair coat recovery with no changes in blood pressure.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies, but human population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the safety and use of oral minoxidil in children for treating hair disorders and hypertension.
results_summary: Low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) was found to be a potentially safe option for treating hair disorders in children, while moderate and high doses were deemed unsafe. The study included data from 442 pediatric patients across various conditions.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients aged 0 to 18 years old.
effective_dosage: Low-dose oral minoxidil (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of mesotherapy with minoxidil 5% for treating androgenetic alopecia (AGA), including its limitations, dosing, and technique.
results_summary: The study found that mesotherapy with minoxidil demonstrated excellent statistical significance and high patient satisfaction, though two studies noted uncommon adverse effects. Recent research suggests mesotherapy for alopecia is effective with a low risk of side effects.
population_specificity: Patients with patterned hair loss (PHL) or androgenetic alopecia (AGA) of both sexes.
effective_dosage: 5% minoxidil (specific frequency not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of topical minoxidil 5% solution and platelet-rich plasma (PRP) in treating alopecia areata (AA).
results_summary: Both minoxidil and PRP showed efficacy in treating AA, with no statistically significant difference in outcomes (p = 0.483). The study concluded that both treatments were similarly effective, but larger and longer-term studies are needed for confirmation.
population_specificity: Patients aged 10-45 years with alopecia areata, of any gender, visiting Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre, Karachi, Pakistan.
effective_dosage: Topical minoxidil 5% solution applied twice daily (six pubs/time).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining platelet-rich plasma (PRP) with minoxidil for treating androgenetic alopecia (AGA) compared to using minoxidil or PRP alone.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that PRP combined with minoxidil significantly improved hair growth (density and diameter) and patient satisfaction compared to minoxidil or PRP alone. The pooled results showed statistically significant increases in hair density and thickness.
population_specificity: Patients with androgenetic alopecia (AGA) of both genders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic response of intradermal Minoxidil (MMP®) with the standard home administration of Minoxidil 5% solution in treating Female Pattern Hair Loss (FPHL).
results_summary: Both treatments were generally effective with no significant overall difference, but intradermal Minoxidil showed better response in parietal-vertex regions for less advanced cases, while standard treatment performed better in other regions.
population_specificity: 16 adult women with FPHL, untreated for at least 6 months.
effective_dosage: Intradermal Minoxidil 0.5% (monthly sessions) and Minoxidil 5% solution (once daily).
study_duration: 4 months (monthly sessions) with reassessment at 6 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Minoxidil, as a lysyl hydroxylase inhibitor, could ameliorate cardiac outflow tract septation defects in Tbx1 mutant fetuses.
results_summary: Prenatal Minoxidil treatment improved cardiac outflow tract septation in Tbx1 mutant fetuses but had no effect on wild-type fetuses, suggesting targeted efficacy in the mutant model. The study linked TBX1 deficiency to ECM-related gene dysregulation and demonstrated that inhibiting collagen cross-linking reduced septation defects.
population_specificity: Tbx1 mutant mouse fetuses (modeling DiGeorge syndrome) and wild-type controls.
study_duration: Early prenatal treatment (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 5% topical minoxidil solution could effectively treat congenital triangular alopecia (CTA) in an adolescent patient.
results_summary: The patient showed improvement with the appearance of terminal hairs after two months of treatment, and the affected area was fully covered with dense terminal hairs after eight months, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Adolescent boy with congenital triangular alopecia (CTA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the ocular side effects of long-term topical minoxidil use in a patient with androgenic alopecia.
results_summary: The study found that long-term minoxidil use was associated with increased intraocular pressure and diplopia, which improved upon discontinuation. The patient required ongoing topical therapy to manage intraocular pressure.
population_specificity: 31-year-old male with androgenic alopecia.

study_goal: To compare patient-reported outcomes of topical finasteride/minoxidil versus oral finasteride for treating male androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: At six weeks, 62.2% reported improved hair appearance and 44.1% reported improved self-esteem with topical finasteride/minoxidil; 11.8% reported adverse events. The treatment was effective but not superior to oral finasteride, with lower adherence for topical use.
population_specificity: Men with androgenetic alopecia in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether maintaining topical minoxidil when initiating low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) reduces the occurrence of "dread shed."
results_summary: The study found that 5.2% of patients experienced "dread shed," lower than previously reported, and overlapping topical minoxidil with LDOM did not significantly impact its occurrence.
population_specificity: Patients seen at New York University Langone Health Dermatology prescribed LDOM from 2008 to 2023.
effective_dosage: Low-dose oral minoxidil (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of topical minoxidil in enhancing beard growth in transgender individuals assigned female at birth (t-AFAB) undergoing gender-affirming hormone therapy (GAHT).
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant increase in facial hair growth over six months, particularly in the upper lip and chin areas, as measured by the Ferriman-Gallwey modified score. Minoxidil use was associated with better beard development compared to a control group relying solely on GAHT.
population_specificity: t-AFAB individuals with incomplete beard development, on GAHT for at least six months (n=16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of microneedle minoxidil combined with triamcinolone acetonide compared to topical application alone in treating alopecia areata.
results_summary: The treated group showed significantly lower SALT and DLQI scores, higher complete response (78.33%) and total effective rates (95%), with no significant difference in adverse reactions or cost compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 230 patients with alopecia areata.
effective_dosage: Experimental group: microneedle treatment once a week plus topical minoxidil and triamcinolone acetonide twice daily; control group: topical minoxidil and triamcinolone acetonide twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of topical betamethasone dipropionate versus topical minoxidil in treating alopecia areata (AA).
results_summary: The study found that topical minoxidil (5%) showed efficacy in 42% of patients, significantly lower than the 74% efficacy observed with betamethasone. The difference was statistically significant (P = 0.001).
population_specificity: 100 patients (aged 18-50) with grades S1-S3 AA of less than three months duration, including both genders.

study_goal: To assess the knowledge, attitude, and practice patterns among dermatologists in Saudi Arabia regarding the use of low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) for hair loss.
results_summary: Most dermatologists identified patterned hair loss as the primary indication for LDOM, and hypertrichosis as a common side effect. However, many did not prescribe LDOM due to its unavailability in local pharmacies.
population_specificity: Dermatologists practicing in Saudi Arabia (n=84).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of daily oral minoxidil (5 mg) versus twice-daily topical minoxidil (5%) over 24 weeks in men with androgenetic alopecia (AGA).
results_summary: Oral minoxidil did not demonstrate superiority over topical minoxidil in terminal or total hair density on the frontal scalp but showed a slight advantage on the vertex area in photographic analysis. Adverse effects like hypertrichosis (49%) and headache (14%) were more common in the oral group.
population_specificity: Men aged 18-55 with AGA (Norwood-Hamilton scale 3V, 4V, or 5V).
effective_dosage: Oral minoxidil 5 mg daily or topical minoxidil 5% twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of combined PRP therapy with topical minoxidil versus PRP monotherapy in reducing hair loss and promoting hair regeneration.
results_summary: The study found that PRP combined with minoxidil significantly improved hair shaft diameter at all measured intervals (1, 2, and 3 months) and hair follicle density at the 3-month mark compared to PRP alone.
population_specificity: 40 male participants with androgenetic alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore a potential link between minoxidil use and retinal vascular disorders, specifically central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) with cystoid macular edema (CME).
results_summary: The study reported a case of CRVO with CME in a young, healthy patient taking minoxidil for hair loss, which resolved after discontinuing the medication. The findings suggest a possible adverse drug event, though no definitive causation was established.
population_specificity: Young, otherwise healthy patient taking minoxidil for hair loss with no known vascular risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a three-layer dissolving microneedle (TDMN) formulation of Minoxidil for improving drug penetration and reducing irritation compared to traditional topical administration.
results_summary: The TDMN formulation showed significantly higher drug permeation (165.28 ± 31.87 ug/cm2) compared to Minoxidil cream (46.03 ± 8.5 ug/cm2), with no potential for irritation or toxicity based on HET-CAM and hemolysis tests. The TDMN2 formula retained higher drug concentrations in the skin, suggesting improved efficacy for alopecia areata therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (ex-vivo and in vivo dermatokinetic tests were conducted).
effective_dosage: Not specified (TDMN2 formulation details not provided).

study_goal: To assess dermatology providers' attitudes and recommendation behaviors regarding oral minoxidil for treating androgenetic alopecia (AGA).
results_summary: Most providers (81%) supported oral minoxidil for AGA, with 92% feeling comfortable prescribing it and 83% finding it better than topical minoxidil. Patient satisfaction (78%) and tolerability (89%) were high, though support varied by years in practice.
population_specificity: Dermatology practitioners (MD/DOs, NPs, PAs) across the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of topical minoxidil (TM) and low-dose oral minoxidil (LDOM) in treating scarring alopecia.
results_summary: Most participants experienced disease stabilization and hair regrowth with TM and LDOM, though results were mixed. The treatments were generally well-tolerated, but some side effects were noted.
population_specificity: Patients with central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, frontal fibrosing alopecia, lichen planopilaris, and traction alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to identify a follicle-specific delivery vehicle to reduce systemic absorption of dutasteride, not Minoxidil.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss Minoxidil or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on dutasteride, not Minoxidil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on plant species used for hair growth and evaluate methodological aspects of related studies.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Minoxidil's effects, focusing instead on broader phytotherapeutic compounds for hair growth.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of topical minoxidil in the multidisciplinary management of filler-induced alopecia.
results_summary: The study reported the use of topical minoxidil as part of a treatment regimen for filler-induced alopecia, but specific efficacy outcomes for minoxidil alone were not detailed. The multidisciplinary approach, including minoxidil, demonstrated potential for cosmetic recovery.
population_specificity: A 21-year-old female with localized skin necrosis and alopecia following HA filler injections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of combining PRP with minoxidil and finasteride/spironolactone as adjuncts to hair transplantation for androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: The study found that combining PRP with minoxidil and finasteride/spironolactone significantly improved follicle survival rates, growth rates, and hair strength compared to drug therapy alone.
population_specificity: 30 patients with androgenetic alopecia.
study_duration: August 2019 to December 2022 (approximately 3 years and 4 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of a hair tonic containing 1% teak leaf extract (HT-teak) against 5% minoxidil and a placebo in treating androgenic alopecia (AGA).
results_summary: The minoxidil group showed significant increases in target area hair count (TAHC) and anagen-to-telogen ratio (A/T), along with reduced hair shedding, similar to the HT-teak group. No adverse effects like skin irritation, sexual dysfunction, or palpitation were reported for minoxidil.
population_specificity: 81 subjects with androgenic alopecia (AGA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the prevention and management of docetaxel-induced chemotherapy-induced alopecia (CIA) and persistent CIA (pCIA), including the role of minoxidil in promoting hair regrowth.
results_summary: The abstract mentions minoxidil as one of the treatment options to promote hair regrowth in docetaxel-induced CIA, but it does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes related to minoxidil.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing chemotherapy-induced alopecia (CIA) or persistent CIA (pCIA) due to docetaxel treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore current trends in minimally invasive treatments, including topical minoxidil, for managing androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: The study found that injectable growth factor formulations and dutasteride showed clinically significant results, while topical minoxidil was used as a control in some comparisons. Overall, growth factors demonstrated satisfactory efficacy in treating androgenetic alopecia.
population_specificity: Patients with androgenetic alopecia (no further specifics provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the potential of drug repositioning, including Minoxidil, as a promising approach in regenerative medicine and cosmetics.
results_summary: The abstract mentions Minoxidil as a successful example of drug repositioning in regenerative medicine and cosmetics, but specific results regarding its effects are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of FDA-approved treatments, including minoxidil, for androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: Minoxidil was found to offer stability and, in some cases, improvement in scalp coverage for androgenetic alopecia. The abstract suggests it is an effective treatment option among multiple interventions.
population_specificity: Individuals with androgenetic alopecia (no further specificity provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of 5% minoxidil in treating filler-induced alopecia (FIA) when combined with other therapies.
results_summary: All three patients experienced gradual hair regrowth with treatments that included 5% minoxidil, corticosteroids, and in one case, microneedling. The study suggests that early intervention with these therapies can prevent permanent hair follicle damage.
population_specificity: Three females who developed hair loss after cosmetic filler injections (hyaluronic acid or autologous fat grafting).
